marketNews.title: Target APBN 2025 Revised: Deficit Widens, Economic Growth Slows
marketNews.content: The Ministry of Finance reported the APBN realization up to the first half of 2025 (1H25) in a working meeting with the DPR Budget Agency on Tuesday (1 July). Important points from the presentation are as follows: State revenue fell by 9 percent year-on-year (YoY) in 1H25, reaching only 40 percent of the 2025 APBN target (versus 47 percent in 1H24). This achievement is slightly better than the 5-month 2025 (5M25) result, which declined 11 percent YoY, mainly because the June 2025 figure already started to grow positively in double-digit annual terms. Tax revenue declined 7 percent YoY in 1H25, improving compared with the 5M25 realization that fell 10 percent. According to Finance Minister Sri Mulyani, the contraction in state revenue during 1H25 was mainly caused by weaker commodity prices, the transfer of state-owned enterprise dividends to the State Treasury, and the cancellation of the 12 percent value-added tax (except for luxury goods). Government spending, on the other hand, grew about 0.6 percent YoY in 1H25 and reached 39 percent of the 2025 APBN target (versus 42 percent in 1H24). This result improved compared with the 5M25 realization, which fell 11 percent YoY. The acceleration of spending was driven primarily by the opening of budget blocking after an efficiency initiative. The realization of revenue and spending during 1H25 resulted in a deficit of IDR 204.2 trillion, equivalent to 0.84 percent of GDP (versus 0.34 percent in 1H24). Sri Mulyani stated that the deficit outlook for the APBN until the end of 2025 is projected to reach IDR 662 trillion, or 2.78 percent of GDP, larger than the initial projection of IDR 616.2 trillion or 2.53 percent of GDP. To help close the 2025 APBN deficit, Sri Mulyani recently applied to the DPR for the use of a surplus allocation of IDR 85.6 trillion. Meanwhile, the government also revised the 2025 macro-economic assumptions after considering recent global dynamics and the 1H25 realization. The 2025 economic growth projection was revised down from +5.2 percent YoY to around +4.7-5 percent YoY. Other changes and the assumptions for the 2026 revised APBN can be seen in the table above. Key Takeaway: The APBN realization in 1H25 began to show improvement in June 2025, both in state revenue and government spending. The increase in spending in the second half of 2025 is expected to support economic growth. In addition to accelerated spending, investors should also watch the trade agreement between Indonesia and the United States. The US government plans to announce the trade deal with several countries on Friday (4 July) with a deadline set for Wednesday (9 July).

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics
marketNews.content:
1. US President Donald Trump said that the new tariff rates to be announced by the deadline of 9 July 2025 will range between 10 and 70 percent, higher than the maximum reciprocal tariff announced in April 2025 at 50 percent. He did not specify which countries will receive the tariffs nor which products may face higher rates. Trump said the US will send tariff notices to partner countries starting Friday (4 July), with 10 or 12 letters sent on Friday and the remainder in the following days.
3. The US Labor Statistics Bureau recorded that non-farm payrolls in the United States increased by 147,000 in June 2025 (versus 144,000 in May 2025), exceeding the consensus expectation of 110,000. The US unemployment rate fell to 4.1 percent in June 2025 (versus 4.2 percent in May 2025), better than the consensus expectation of 4.3 percent. These results indicate that the US economy remains resilient despite expectations of turbulence from President Trump's tariff policy. The strong labor market also supports the Federal Reserve's argument to keep interest rates high to curb inflation.
4. The Chairman of the Indonesian Ceramic Industry Association (Asaki), Edy Suyanto, said that the average utilization of the ceramic industry in 1H25 was around 70-71 percent, with production volume rising 16.5 percent YoY to 218 million square meters. Although utilization improved compared with 1H24's 60 percent, it remains below the 1H25 target of 75 percent. He explained that demand for ceramics is stagnant due to weakened consumer purchasing power, a slowdown in the property sector, and suboptimal government projects. He also noted a new challenge: a surge in Indian ceramic imports, estimated to increase by 150 percent in the fourth quarter of 2025, creating oversupply in India and positioning Indonesia as a diversion market for exports due to US tariffs.
5. Reuters reported that the Indonesian Nickel Miners Association (APNI) urged the government to maintain the three-year mining quota to ensure a consistent business climate. The request follows Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia's statement that the government plans to reduce the duration of the work plan and cost budget (RKAB) from three years to one year to better control coal and ore supply. APNI warned that shortening the quota period could create obstacles in the approval process, as thousands of miners would need to apply for quotas each year, and emphasized the importance of medium-term certainty for investment and operational planning.
6. National Development Planning Minister Rachmat Pambudy said that the number of beneficiaries of the Free Nutritious Meal (MBG) program is expected to jump from 5.2 million on 22 June 2025 to 20 million in August 2025, following the completion of staff training and kitchen facility readiness. The government targets 83 million MBG beneficiaries by the end of 2025. During 1H25, the Ministry of Finance recorded that the MBG program's budget realization reached only IDR 5 trillion, about 7 percent of the total allocation. The head of the National Nutrition Agency, Dadan Hindayana, said an additional IDR 50 trillion is needed for November and December 2025.

tickerNews.title: BUKA to continue share buyback with up to IDR 1.1 trillion
tickerNews.content: BUKA announced that it will continue a share buyback program with funds up to approximately IDR 1.1 trillion for the period 7 July to 6 October 2025. The corporate action does not require a shareholders' meeting, thanks to the relaxation granted by the OJK to support market stability. The buyback fund is the remainder of a previous allocation of IDR 1.9 trillion that was used for a buyback conducted from 26 March to 25 June 2025.

tickerNews.title: KRYA directors sell shares, reducing holdings
tickerNews.content: Directors and Commissioners of Bangun Karya Perkasa Jaya, Brigitta Notoatmodjo and Pramana Budihardjo each sold approximately 133 million shares and 40,000 shares of KRYA on 3 July 2025 at a price of IDR 29 per share, lower than the closing price of IDR 278 per share on the same day. Collectively, the divestment represents about 8 percent of KRYA's shares and constitutes the first stage of a takeover by prospective buyers. After the transaction, Brigitta's direct ownership in KRYA fell from about 13.87 percent to about 5.88 percent, while Pramana no longer holds any KRYA shares directly. Previously, KRYA announced that PT Bangun Karya Artha Lestari, Hok Gwan (Dharmo Budiono), Brigitta Notoatmodjo, and Pramana Budihardjo would jointly sell 70 percent of KRYA to a group of prospective buyers consisting of Rich Step International Ltd., Green Power Group (LABA), PT EVMOTO Teknologi Indonesia, PT Huashang Investment Group, and PT Cahaya Intan Niaga.

tickerNews.title: MDKA plans gold production from Pani mine starting 1Q26
tickerNews.content: The Head of Corporate Communications of Merdeka Copper Gold, Tom Malik, told Kompas that the company will start producing gold from the Pani gold mine in the first quarter of 2026. He explained that construction progress has reached almost 50 percent as of the first quarter of 2025, with mining operations expected to begin at the end of 2025. The Pani gold mine contains more than 6.9 million ounces of gold, and production capacity is targeted at up to 500,000 ounces per year.

tickerNews.title: GIAA in talks to purchase 50-75 Boeing aircraft
tickerNews.content: The President Director of Garuda Indonesia, Wamildan Tsani Panjaitan, said that the airline is in discussions to buy around 50 to 75 aircraft from Boeing, including Boeing 737 Max 8 and 787-9 models. GIAA aims to operate a total of 120 aircraft for Garuda Indonesia and Citilink within five years, up from 98 aircraft in March 2025. Earlier this week, Bloomberg reported that GIAA is also considering re-operating one Boeing 737 Max 8 that was grounded after the fatal Lion Air crash in 2018.

tickerNews.title: BHIT increases stake in KPIG to 26.11 percent
tickerNews.content: MNC Asia Holding (BHIT), the controlling shareholder of MNC Tourism Indonesia (formerly MNC Land), purchased 4.62 billion shares of KPIG at an average price of IDR 200 per share on 2 July 2025. The total transaction value reached IDR 924 billion. After the transaction, BHIT's ownership in KPIG rose from 21.37 percent to 26.11 percent.

tickerNews.title: Indonesia offers increased aircraft purchases for GIAA and wheat imports for INDF in US tariff negotiations
tickerNews.content: Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said that Indonesia will offer the United States increased purchases of aircraft by Garuda Indonesia (GIAA) and wheat imports by Indofood Sukses Makmur (INDF) as part of the tariff negotiations. Additionally, Indonesia offered a tariff range of 0-5 percent for major US exports, depending on the tariff level imposed by the US on Indonesian imports. The Secretary of the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, Susiwijono Moegiarso, said the Indonesian government asks the US to lower tariffs as much as possible for Indonesia's main export products, including electronics, textiles, and footwear.
